fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \mathbb {C} be category with finite products. A first order hyperdoctrine \mathcal {P} over \mathbb {C} is a contravariant functor \mathcal {P} : { \mathbb {C} }^{ \mathsf {op}} \to \mathbf {Poset} satisfying the following conditions.
\mathcal {P} (C) is a Heyting algebra for each object C \in \mathbb {C}.
For each \mathbb {C}-morphism f : C \to D, the monotone function \mathcal {P} (f) : \mathcal {P} (D) \to \mathcal {P} (C) is a Heyting algebra homomorphism.
For each diagonal morphism \Delta _C : C \to C \times C in \mathbb {C}, the left adjoint to \mathcal {P} ( \Delta _C) at the top element \mathbf {1} \in \mathcal {P} (X) exists.
For each projection \pi : {-} \times C \to {-}, the monotone function \mathcal {P} ( \pi ) \to \mathcal {P} ({-}) \to \mathcal {P} ({-} \times C) has both a left adjoint ( \exists C)_{ \Gamma } and a right adjoint ( \forall C)_{ \Gamma }.
Adapted from Definition 2.1 of Tripos theory in retrospect.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Partial combinatory algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Example 2.3 of Tripos theory in retrospect

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
A partial combinatory algebra (PCA for short) is a set \mathbb {A} equipped with
a partial function ({-}) \cdot ({-}) : \mathbb {A} \times \mathbb {A} \nrightarrow \mathbb {A},
an element \mathsf {k} \in \mathbb {A}, and
an element \mathsf {s} \in \mathbb {A}; satisfying the following conditions.
For every a, b \in \mathbb {A}, ( \mathsf {k} \cdot a) \downarrow, and ( \mathsf {k} \cdot a) \cdot b \equiv a;
For every a, b, c \in \mathbb {A}, ( \mathsf {s} \cdot a) \downarrow, ((s \cdot a) \cdot b) \downarrow, and (( \mathsf {s} \cdot a) \cdot b) \cdot c \equiv (a \cdot c) \cdot (b \cdot c).
